meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>original</radical> <radical>geoduck</radical> had a <kanji>request</kanji>. He wants there to be more geoducks in the world!
reading_mnemonic: The only person that would even hear the geoduck's <kanji>request</kanji> was <reading>Gan</reading>dhi (がん). Gandhi closed his eyes, sat down, and spread the geoduck's request to the rest of the world.

kanji_to_vocab_info.reading: よろしくおねがいします

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of the <radical>yakuza</radical> shows you his <radical>knife</radical>. He says, "This is an <kanji>example</kanji> of a knife."
reading_mnemonic: "This is an <kanji>example</kanji>," the leader of the yakuza tells you. "Next time, I'll show you an example of a <reading>ray</reading> (れい) gun."

meaning_mnemonic: You give a <radical>lid</radical> to a <radical>person</radical> (two of them, in fact), then they put it on a <radical>cross</radical> when you <kanji>graduate</kanji>. It's a symbolic ceremony, putting a lid over a cross, but it's just what you do when you graduate around these parts.
reading_mnemonic: Uh oh, looks like you forgot your lid. They decide not to let you <kanji>graduate</kanji>. <reading>So two</reading> (そつ) more years now until you can graduate, it seems. So two more years?! Just for forgetting a lid? Nonsense!

meaning_mnemonic: Next to the <radical>cross</radical> we combine our <radical>power</radical> <radical>power</radical> <radical>power</radical> so that we have <kanji>cooperation</kanji>. And with our powers combined, we become stronger than we ever could have been apart, lifting the cross above our heads!
reading_mnemonic: Nowhere is the power of cooperation more apparent than in <reading>きょう</reading>と. When invaders are attacking, when the townspeople want to rebel, when there is a kitty up a tree, the people combine their power from all reaches of Japan and cross into きょうと to put a stop to the madness through cooperation.

meaning_mnemonic: You try to be <radical>private</radical>, but because of your <radical>big</radical> <radical>hair</radical> you end up having to <kanji>participate</kanji> in everything. Can you imagine people asking for volunteers or something, and you trying to look inconspicuous with your big hair? Of course they're going to notice you and make you participate.
reading_mnemonic: You know who has big hair and loves to <kanji>participate</kanji> in everything? <reading>San</reading>ta-san (さん)! Well, his hair is more big on the bottom (it's a beard) than whatever you have on your head, but hair is hair. And he participates in present-giving in every house in the world! See? Big hair = participation!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>circumference</radical> radical and the <kanji>circumference</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: Practice how to measure the <kanji>circumference</kanji> of an item by using your <reading>shoe</reading> (しゅう). Your shoe is kind of round, and it's free. I mean it's right there on your foot.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>mouth</radical> of a <radical>well</radical> will <kanji>surround</kanji> you if you fall into it. The mouth of a well is the opening of the well, and if you fall into that well, the mouth as well as the rest of the well will surround you.
reading_mnemonic: The well walls <kanji>surround</kanji> you as you look up to the mouth once again. This time you see an <reading>ea</reading>gle (い) flying overhead. You call out to the eagle to save you and the eagle comes swooping down into the well and flies you out to safety. What a nice eagle!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>mouth</radical> that is <radical>old</radical> is going to be <kanji>hard</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You touch the old man's <kanji>hard</kanji> mouth and it crumbles away, revealing the face of a <reading>子</reading> (こ) inside.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>grain</radical>'s <radical>child</radical> will grow with the <kanji>seasons</kanji>. In spring the grain is born, it grows in summer, is harvested in fall, and dies in winter.
reading_mnemonic: All of the <kanji>seasons</kanji> have their own special <reading>key</reading> (き). As they change, that season's key appears and unlocks the next step in the grain's life.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>roof</radical> that became the <radical>origin</radical> of all roofs was <kanji>perfect</kanji>. It was tall and wide so it could fit and protect everyone. And the dimensions were perfect too.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>perfect</kanji> roof was commissioned by Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん). We got all of the carpenters and home makers and construction workers he'd conquered together and tasked them with making the first roof, but only if they made it absolutely perfect.

meaning_mnemonic: There is a <radical>treasure</radical> on top of a <radical>narwhal</radical> who wears a <radical>towel</radical> that will grant your greatest <kanji>wish</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: In order to open the treasure and get your <kanji>wish</kanji>, you need the <reading>key</reading> (き). The narwhal knows where it's hidden, so you'll have to convince it to tell you where the key is.

meaning_mnemonic: If you live in the <radical>now</radical>, there’s a good chance your <radical>heart</radical> controls your <kanji>thought</kanji> process. You don’t have time to think with your brain, you need an answer now so you use your heart to make decisions and thought process.
reading_mnemonic: You're living in the now and letting your heart control all your <kanji>thought</kanji>s. Why are you following your heart? You found you only have one <reading>年</reading> (ねん) to live, so you have to live for the now.

meaning_mnemonic: If your <radical>fingers</radical> are strong enough, you can take an <radical>axe</radical> and <kanji>fold</kanji> it in half. But be careful not to <kanji>bend</kanji> it too far, or you might just <kanji>break</kanji> it!
reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately, as you <kanji>fold</kanji> these axes in half you realize they come in <reading>sets</reading> (せつ), so there are twice the axes you thought there would be. To compensate, you start folding them in sets too.

meaning_mnemonic: Causing <radical>death</radical> at every turn, the <radical>moon</radical> <radical>king</radical> sits inside his moon, getting ready to cause death on anything in his sights. Sounds a lot like the Death Star from a certain movie. One of which is "Star Wars: A New <kanji>Hope</kanji>."
reading_mnemonic: The name A New <kanji>Hope</kanji>, as we all know, comes from the ending where the moon king's son sends a <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう) ball into that little opening and knocks it out of the sky.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tree</radical> with <radical>talent</radical> can become <kanji>lumber</kanji>. Not all trees can do this. Only the talented ones are able to turn themselves into lumber or <kanji>material</kanji>, to be used for a million different things.
reading_mnemonic: Trees can be turned into all kinds of things, but this one wants to use its <kanji>lumber</kanji> and <kanji>material</kanji> to build a <reading>xy</reading>lophone (ざい). It's the most difficult instrument to create, so it suits the talent level of this tree!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>bundle</radical> radical and the <kanji>bundle</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: You should always <kanji>bundle</kanji> your <reading>sock</reading>s (そく). If you don't, there is a 100% chance you'll lose all of the left ones.

meaning_mnemonic: When climbing a <radical>tree</radical> in <radical>public</radical>, it’s best to choose a <kanji>pine</kanji>. Pine trees offer the most coverage, so you’ll be able to hide, even out in public.
reading_mnemonic: In case you fall, someone has laid <reading>mats</reading> (まつ) out around the base of the <kanji>pine</kanji> tree. That way, you’ll land on the mats should something unfortunate happen.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Yakuza</radical> <radical>bars</radical> barely exist. The <kanji>remainder</kanji> of them aren't even in Japan.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>remainder</kanji> of the yakuza bars aren't in Japan. Strangely, they are all in <reading>Zan</reading>zibar (ざん).

meaning_mnemonic:
A <radical>white</radical> guy jumps into a <radical>pool</radical> with a <kanji>target</kanji> painted on the bottom. He's aiming for the target, of course.

This kanji can also mean <kanji>-al</kanji>, as in the endings you get on some English adjectives. You know, like the pool is artifici-al. Or painting a target down there is not practic-al. That kind of -al.
reading_mnemonic: This white dude is a huge <reading>techie</reading> (てき) so he has electronic enhancements that make sure he hits the <kanji>target</kanji>. Being a techie has its advantages.

meaning_mnemonic: You tie a <radical>thread</radical> on your finger before jumping in the <radical>pool</radical> to remind yourself of the <kanji>promise</kanji> you made to your mother. The thread represents the promise you made to mow the lawn after you finished swimming in the pool.
reading_mnemonic: After you get out of the pool, you keep the <kanji>promise</kanji> you made to your mother. So you get on your <reading>yak</reading> (やく) powered mower and trim the grass. Yes, your mower is pulled by a yak. It’s very efficient.

meaning_mnemonic: You put <radical>flowers</radical> on a <radical>cloud</radical> and call it <kanji>art</kanji>. Not everyone agrees that your flower cloud art is actually art, but you know it is.
reading_mnemonic: Your beautiful <kanji>art</kanji> is going to be displayed at a <reading>gay</reading> (げい) club. Imagine the pride you feel about having your art on display.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Crab</radical>s in the <radical>dirt</radical> make a great <kanji>foundation</kanji> for a seaside hut. It's right on the seashore, where all the crabs dig their holes in the dirt. But as they get old and die, their bodies form a strong base. Perfect for the foundation of a building like this!
reading_mnemonic: Remember, a good <kanji>foundation</kanji> is the <reading>key</reading> (き) to a good house. No, literally. You have to use a piece of the foundation to make the key to your house.

meaning_mnemonic: Everyone has a <radical>soul</radical> in their <radical>life</radical>, and that soul shapes their <kanji>gender</kanji>. It's not just about body parts — it's about what's inside. In the end, it's one's <kanji> nature</kanji> that truly matters.
reading_mnemonic: Once you've decided what your <kanji>gender</kanji> is, someone comes to your house and lays a <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい) on your shoulders. "This is now your <kanji>nature</kanji>," they say, lifting the saber. It's official! It's in all the newspapers, there's a parade, and everyone pats you on the back. Thanks, gender saber!

meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>tree</radical> wants to <radical>kiss</radical> you, it's a sign of your <kanji>status</kanji>. Only someone of high status would be worthy enough to receive the gnarly but gentle kiss of a tree. Trees don't kiss just anyone, you know.
reading_mnemonic: The best way to convince a tree of your <kanji>status</kanji> is to say "cock-a-doodle-doo" at it, like a <reading>cock</reading> (かく), i.e. a male chicken. Trees really place a lot of status on the ability to sound like a cock crowing.

meaning_mnemonic: In a <radical>private</radical> place on the <radical>moon</radical>, you hide two <radical>spoon</radical>s that give you a special <kanji>ability</kanji>. It's the ability to predict the future! The private moon spoons reflect the knowledge of time and space into your brain. Now that's a cool ability!
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>ability</kanji> to predict the future makes you famous and now everyone knows your name: <reading>No</reading>stradamus (のう)! And now that people know about your name and special ability, everyone will love you!

meaning_mnemonic: If you have a <radical>mustache</radical> and you hit your <radical>forehead</radical> on the <radical>moon</radical>, you’re probably going to break a <kanji>bone</kanji>. Ok, so it doesn’t matter so much if you have a mustache, but if you’re travelling fast enough to make it to the moon, you’re definitely breaking a bone if you run into it.
reading_mnemonic: Outer space is cold, and if you're traveling to the moon, you're going to need a lot of <reading>coats</reading> (こつ). All of these coats will keep you warm, even if you do end up breaking your forehead <kanji>bone</kanji>.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>cleat</radical>-wearing <radical>woman</radical> is walking on someone's back, but she doesn't want to hurt him, so she has to be very <kanji>gentle</kanji>. Cleats are sharp and pointy, and not designed for back-walking, so she's being extra gentle right now.
reading_mnemonic: Actually, the person she's being <kanji>gentle</kanji> with is her <reading>da</reading>d (だ). No one would ever want to hurt their dad, especially if he's asked you to walk gently on his back as a way of giving him a massage.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Rain</radical> makes up one <radical>part</radical> of this, and the rest is air or something. I imagine this is what people thought the <kanji>atmosphere</kanji> was made out of thousands of years ago.
reading_mnemonic: Turns out, studying the <kanji>atmosphere</kanji> is <reading>fun</reading> (ふん)!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>origin</radical> of the <radical>geoduck</radical> is a pretty <kanji>stubborn</kanji> one. The geoduck race is so stubborn that it refused to evolve into an animal that made any sense. Hence, the origin of the geoduck is one of stubbornness.
reading_mnemonic: You know who else was <kanji>stubborn</kanji>? <reading>Gan</reading>dhi (がん). Gandhi believed in non-violent resistance and he was pretty stubborn about it.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>gate</radical> to <radical>talent</radical> is now <kanji>closed</kanji>. In fact, the gate to talent is always closed. It's not like anyone can just waltz in and get themselves some talent. You have to work for it! You have to work hard to get through that closed gate to talent!
reading_mnemonic: Outside the talent gate that's always <kanji>closed</kanji>, <reading>hay</reading> (へい) is piled up to make beds for the people who are still trying to get in. Who knows how long they'll be there outside the closed gate, sleeping in the hay, but they're all working hard to become talented.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>well</radical> radical and the <kanji>well</kanji> kanji are the same.
reading_mnemonic: Each time you go to the town <kanji>well</kanji>, there's a giant <reading>ea</reading>gle (い) hiding inside, just waiting for you to show up.

meaning_mnemonic: The best kind of flowers to grow in your window? Strawberry, obviously. Yes, there are strawberry flowers — it's actually the flowers that turn into the strawberries, you know. And they're perfect as window flowers because they need a ton of light. That's why all your window flowers are strawberries.
reading_mnemonic: Believe it or not, your <kanji>strawberry</kanji> is the only cure for an <reading>itchy Go</reading>dzilla (いちご).

meaning_mnemonic: One <radical>animal</radical> that is particularly  <radical>good</radical> is the <kanji>wolf</kanji>. Wolves have a bad reputation, but actually they're very, very good animals.
reading_mnemonic: A <kanji>wolf</kanji> might be good, but if you run into one, all you can do is scream <reading>Oh 神</reading>!” (おおかみ).
